title: The Old Testament
summary: The Old Testament is the first and foundational portion of Christian Scripture — 39 books recording God's creation of the world, his covenant with Israel, his moral law given through Moses, and his prophetic promises pointing forward to the Messiah — the essential foundation without which the life, death, and resurrection of Jesus Christ cannot be understood.
author: EduWiki Team

title: The New Testament
summary: The New Testament is the fulfillment of everything the Old Testament promised — 27 books written in Greek within a generation of the resurrection of Jesus Christ, proclaiming the good news of redemption through his Son and constituting the most influential set of documents in human history.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Isaiah
summary: Isaiah son of Amoz is the greatest prophet of the Old Testament — whose 66 chapters encompass the highest poetry, deepest theology, and most explicit messianic prophecy in Hebrew Scripture, cited more than all other prophets combined in the New Testament, and whose words the risen Christ himself commanded the Nephites to search diligently.
author: EduWiki Team

title: The Pentateuch
summary: The Pentateuch — the five books of Moses (Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, and Deuteronomy) — is the foundation of the entire Bible, narrating creation, the fall, the covenant with Abraham, the Exodus, and the giving of God's law at Sinai, forming the bedrock on which all of Jewish, Christian, and Islamic faith is built.
author: EduWiki Team

title: The Gospels
summary: The four Gospels — Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John — are the four accounts of the life, ministry, death, and resurrection of Jesus Christ that stand at the center of the New Testament and the center of the Christian faith, written that readers 'might believe that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of God' and have life in his name.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Thomas Jefferson
summary: Thomas Jefferson (1743–1826) was the principal author of the Declaration of Independence, the third President of the United States, and one of the most intellectually gifted statesmen in the history of Western civilization, who articulated the God-given rights of man with a clarity that still echoes through every free nation on earth.
author: EduWiki Team

title: The French Revolution
summary: The French Revolution (1789–1799) was the violent upheaval that toppled the French monarchy, executed thousands in the Reign of Terror, and gave rise to Napoleon Bonaparte — a decade that transformed Europe and demonstrated, with terrible clarity, what happens when a civilization abandons its Christian roots in the name of abstract ideology.
author: EduWiki Team

title: The Sermon on the Mount
summary: The Sermon on the Mount (Matthew 5–7) is the greatest single discourse in human history — the extended teaching in which Jesus Christ laid out the ethics and vision of the Kingdom of God that define Christian discipleship, containing the Beatitudes, the Lord's Prayer, and the most demanding and beautiful moral teaching ever recorded.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Homer
summary: Homer is the name given to the poet responsible for the Iliad and the Odyssey — the two foundational epics of Western literature — composed in ancient Greece around the 8th century BC and exploring war, homecoming, heroism, mortality, and the human heart with a depth and beauty that has never been surpassed.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Dante Alighieri
summary: Dante Alighieri (1265–1321) was the greatest poet of medieval Christendom and the author of the Divine Comedy — a visionary journey through Hell, Purgatory, and Paradise that synthesizes medieval Christian theology, classical philosophy, and vernacular poetry into a transcendent masterwork that maps the spiritual life with unmatched precision and beauty.
author: EduWiki Team

title: John Locke
summary: John Locke (1632–1704) was the English philosopher whose ideas about natural rights, consent of the governed, and limited government became the philosophical foundation of the American founding — his Two Treatises of Government arguing that legitimate government derives from consent and exists solely to protect God-given rights to life, liberty, and property.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Natural Law
summary: Natural law is the philosophical and theological doctrine that there exists a universal moral order — discoverable by human reason — that stands above all human law and provides the standard by which all positive law is to be judged, and which forms the philosophical backbone of Western jurisprudence, Christian moral theology, and the American founding.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Rhetoric
summary: Rhetoric — the art of persuasion through language — is one of the three foundational disciplines of the classical liberal arts (the trivium: grammar, logic, and rhetoric) and has been studied and practiced since ancient Greece, providing the indispensable tools for anyone who wishes to teach, lead, preach, or persuade with the power of well-ordered words.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Astronomy
summary: Astronomy is the oldest science — the study of celestial objects, space, and the physical universe — practiced by every civilization in history and cherished by the Christian tradition as the discipline that reveals the glory of God written in the heavens, from the ancient Babylonians to Copernicus, Galileo, Newton, and the modern discovery of billions of galaxies.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Medieval Europe
summary: Medieval Europe — roughly the thousand years between the fall of Rome and the Renaissance — was not the 'Dark Ages' of secular myth but the age in which Christianity transformed the ruins of Rome into the civilization of Christendom, building the great cathedrals, founding the universities, and establishing the foundations on which the modern West stands.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Poetry
summary: Poetry is the oldest and most elevated form of literary art — language shaped by rhythm, sound, image, and compression into something that reaches places plain prose cannot — and from the Psalms of David to Homer, Dante, Shakespeare, and Milton, it has been the medium through which human beings express their deepest experiences of beauty, grief, love, and encounter with God.
author: EduWiki Team

title: George Washington
summary: George Washington (1732–1799) was the commanding general of the Continental Army, the presiding officer of the Constitutional Convention, and the first President of the United States — a man of extraordinary character whose self-discipline, courage, and selfless devotion to republican ideals made the American experiment possible.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Benjamin Franklin
summary: Benjamin Franklin (1706–1790) was printer, scientist, diplomat, philosopher, and Founding Father — perhaps the most versatile genius in American history, who harnessed lightning from the sky and persuaded France to save the Revolution, and whose self-made life became the archetypal American story of industry, wit, and practical wisdom.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Abraham Lincoln
summary: Abraham Lincoln (1809–1865) was the sixteenth President of the United States, the commander-in-chief who preserved the Union through the agony of the Civil War, and the statesman who ended slavery in America — a self-educated man of the frontier whose biblical faith, moral clarity, and literary genius lifted the American experiment to a new and more complete understanding of its own founding promise.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Edmund Burke
summary: Edmund Burke (1729–1797) was the Irish-born British statesman and philosopher regarded as the father of modern conservatism — whose profound critique of the French Revolution in his *Reflections on the Revolution in France* (1790) articulated the enduring case for ordered liberty, inherited institutions, and the accumulated wisdom of tradition over abstract ideological radicalism.
author: EduWiki Team

title: G.K. Chesterton
summary: G.K. Chesterton (1874–1936) was the English writer, journalist, and Christian apologist whose dazzling wit, paradoxical brilliance, and deep Catholic faith produced some of the most quotable and persuasive writing in defense of Christianity ever penned — a man of letters who C.S. Lewis credited with first moving him toward Christian faith.
author: EduWiki Team

title: John Milton
summary: John Milton (1608–1674) was the greatest English poet after Shakespeare — a classically trained Puritan scholar whose epic *Paradise Lost* (1667) retells the story of the Fall of Man with such theological depth, psychological insight, and sublime poetic power that it stands as the supreme achievement of English letters and one of the most important works of Christian literature ever written.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Frederick Douglass
summary: Frederick Douglass (c. 1818–1895) was the most important African American leader of the nineteenth century — a man who escaped slavery, taught himself to read, and became the most powerful orator and writer in the abolitionist cause, whose life was the most eloquent possible argument that slavery was incompatible with the founding ideals of the American republic.
author: EduWiki Team

title: William Wilberforce
summary: William Wilberforce (1759–1833) was the British Member of Parliament and Evangelical Christian whose twenty-six-year parliamentary campaign to abolish the slave trade in the British Empire stands as one of the greatest moral achievements in the history of democratic government — proof that a single person of faith, conviction, and tireless persistence can change the world.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Immanuel Kant
summary: Immanuel Kant (1724–1804) was the German philosopher whose *Critique of Pure Reason* (1781) fundamentally reoriented Western philosophy by distinguishing what the human mind can know from what transcends its reach — and whose moral philosophy, centered on the categorical imperative, provided the most rigorous account of duty and human dignity in the modern philosophical tradition.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Adam Smith
summary: Adam Smith (1723–1790) was the Scottish moral philosopher and economist whose *The Wealth of Nations* (1776) founded the discipline of modern economics — demonstrating how free exchange, division of labor, and price signals coordinate the activity of millions to produce prosperity, within a moral framework grounded in sympathy, virtue, and providential social order.
author: EduWiki Team
